label: ANA MENDIETA: RETURNING TO THE MATERNAL SOURCE

description.@value:
This gallery reunites five Images / Artworks created by the Cuban artist Ana
Mendieta (1948-1985) between 1972 and 1984, reflecting her work using different
media tools (photography, performance, sculpture, drawing illustration, natural
elements) and exploring the topics related to exile, connection between humans and
earth, women condition in a patriarchal context and the violence it is subjected to,
and it's Latin American roots connected with the spiritual Cuban rituals. These
chosen images are connected in different ways to tell her artist and life history, as a chronological and autobiographical process; all of
them are contained in the MoMA's Collection. The "Photography Series" has been a
way to present her different ideas, questioning traditional beauty concepts and
representing spiritual and earth images through silhouettes and her body. At the end
of her life (1985), ni 1984 presented a book with Carle Andre, an artist, her husband, and his suspected killer, a book of nature illustrations. In addition, in his sculpture
"Nile Born" (1984), an inner channel that suggests a vaginal cavity created with sand,
synthesizes herwholeinterest in "returning to the material source" as she stated, and generates a synthesis of his artistic proposal before his death. Her vast
influence on Feminism Art, Land Art, Body Art, and Performance is known around the world. Moreover, despite her short life, she was one of the most influential Latin American contemporary artists of the 20th century, and that is why it is important to honor his life.

metadata.label: Subject
metadata.value: Feminist Art; Photography; Body Art; Self-Portrait; Performance; Latin American Art

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value:
Mendieta integrated multiple practices and media -such as film, video, performance, and photography- in diverse experimental series of images. In the Untitled (Facial Cosmetic Variations) (1972) series, she appeared mangled, deformed, or concealed by varied
instruments such as wigs, makeup, pantyhose, etc. These photos belong to this group of images and tried to challenge the conventional notions of women's beauty by transforming herself in several ways through self-portraits.

metadata.label: Subject
metadata.value: Feminist Art; Body Art; Performance; Photography; Self-Portrait; Latin American Art

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value:
Mendieta integrated multiple practices and media -such as film, video, performance, and photography- in diverse experimental series of images. In the Untitled (Glass on Body Imprints) (1972) series, she took a glass pane and moved it through her body, distorting
her face and her "feminine beauty". These photos belong to this group of images and tried to challenge the conventional notions of women's beauty by transforming herself in several ways through self-portraits. For these photographs, Mendieta presses her face and parts of her body onto a square sheet of plexiglass, distorting and transforming the appearance of her physical features and youthful beauty. By using her own body as a malleable, sculptural material, Mendieta eliminates traditional visual components of image making, relying instead on the power of her own body as a tool to reexamine the archetype human subject and the gaze in photography. The series marks the artist's first works of the time- based performance for which she would become known.

metadata.label: Contributor
metadata.value: Gift of Gwen and Peter Norton

metadata.label: Subject
metadata.value: Feminist Art; Land Art; Body Art; Performance; Photography; Latin American Art

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value:
The "Siluetas comprises more than 200 earth-body works that saw the artist burn, carve,
and mold her silhouette into the landscapes of Lowa (United States) and Mexico. The sculptures made tangible Mendieta's belief of the earth as a goddess, rooted in Afro-Cuban Santería and the indigenous Taíno practices of her homeland. Mendieta's "Silueta Series"
(1973-1980), explores the connections between nature and the female body. This photograph documents an ephemeral sculpture - in the shape of the artist's silhouette and loosely evocative of ancient goddess archetypes - carved directly into the earth with minimal disruption of the environment. Returning to a metaphorical womb and her native Cuban homeland as she molded a feminist subject and land art processes to explore the theme of Exile. She used the natural environment as a perpetual setting throughout her career, most memorably in her earth-works such as Siluetas, which were created in various natural locations with meaning to the artist and adorned with elements indigenous to the areas. The powerful work washed away all evidence of the artist's presence. In doing so, it evoked the cycles of life, of birth and death, and of coming from and returning to the womb/earth- or simply, that unexplained spiritual place of vast mystery paid homage to in ritual such as this performance.

metadata.label: Is part of
metadata.value: Installation view of the gallery "Art as a Verb" in the exhibition "Collection 1970s-Present" (May 15, 2021-ongoing): https://www.moma.org/calendar/galleries

metadata.label: Subject
metadata.value: Drawings; Land Art; Photography; Natural Elements; Feminimist Art; Latin American Art

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: This draw is part of "illustrated Book: Pietre Foglie" and is a result of being awarded the prestigious American Academy residency. In 1983 Mendieta moved to Rome / Italy, where the imagery for Pietre/Foglie was made and the portfolio was published by "Edizione R. R. Bulla. Rome", which Mendieta described as a cross between her native Cuba and New York, held a special sentimental value for the couple, as they were married there in January 1985. Some months after the Carl Andre and Ana Mendieta wedding, which coincided with the presentation of the Pietre/Foglie portfolio at AAM Gallery in Rome, Mendieta's tragic (and controversial) death happened (being his husband accused of pushing her off a 34th-floor).

metadata.label: Type
metadata.value:
Drawings and Prints / One from an illustrated book with twenty lithographs and four
letterpress prints (including cover)

metadata.label: Format
metadata.value: Book Printed by R. Bulla Studio, Rome

metadata.label: Subject
metadata.value: Feminist Art; Sculpture; Natural Elements; Land Art; Latin American Art

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value:
This work embodies the relationship between the female figure and the earth's materials. A wooden form is covered by sand, and the large inner channel suggests a vaginal cavity.  This work was a result of the "Siluetas Series" and is meant to show the organic materials' fragility and it's attached to the physical place were created. 
"Nile Born" is one of the last Siluetas Mendieta made before she died in 1985, and the title refers to Cuba's African heritage.
"The work is an arresting exploration of self, place, belonging, and alienation, concepts that
permeate Mendieta's entire oeuvre of installations, earthworks, performances, videos, and sculptures" (MoMA, Publication excerpt from The Museum of Modern Art, MoMA
Highlights since 1980, New York: The Museum of Modern Art, p. 48).
